skill.name: dast-zap
skill.description: Dynamic application security testing (DAST) using OWASP ZAP (Zed Attack Proxy) with passive and active scanning, API testing, and OWASP Top 10 vulnerability detection. Use when: (1) Performing runtime security testing of web applications and APIs, (2) Detecting vulnerabilities like XSS, SQL injection, and authentication flaws in deployed applications, (3) Automating security scans in CI/CD pipelines with Docker containers, (4) Conducting authenticated testing with session management, (5) Generating security reports with OWASP and CWE mappings for compliance.

security_audit.summary: Legitimate DAST security testing skill using official OWASP ZAP tooling. Contains documentation, configuration templates, and CI/CD workflows for vulnerability scanning. All 465 static findings are false positives - the patterns detected are expected behaviors for security testing documentation (shell commands for running scanners, URLs in documentation, and security terminology explaining vulnerabilities). No malicious intent detected.

content.user_title: Scan web apps for vulnerabilities with OWASP ZAP
content.value_statement: Web applications and APIs often contain security vulnerabilities that manual testing misses. This skill automates comprehensive security scanning using OWASP ZAP, detecting issues like XSS, SQL injection, and authentication flaws. Generate detailed reports mapped to OWASP Top 10 and CWE for compliance.
actual_capabilities: Run baseline and full active scans against web applications
Test REST, GraphQL, SOAP, and WebSocket APIs using OpenAPI specifications
Configure authenticated scanning with form-based, OAuth, and token authentication
Generate security reports in HTML, JSON, XML, and SARIF formats
Integrate security scanning into GitHub Actions and GitLab CI pipelines
Map findings to OWASP Top 10 2021 and CWE identifiers
limitations: Requires Docker to run ZAP container images
Active scanning performs real attacks and requires explicit authorization
Does not perform source code analysis (use SAST tools for that)
Cannot scan applications behind authentication without proper test credentials

use_cases.title: CI/CD security gates
use_cases.description: Add automated security scans to deployment pipelines with GitHub Actions or GitLab CI

use_cases.title: API vulnerability testing
use_cases.description: Scan REST and GraphQL APIs using OpenAPI specifications to find injection flaws and authorization issues

use_cases.title: Quick security checks
use_cases.description: Run baseline scans during development to catch security issues early before they reach production

prompt_templates.title: Quick baseline scan
prompt_templates.prompt: Run an OWASP ZAP baseline scan against https://staging.example.com and generate a report at ./zap-report.html

prompt_templates.title: API security test
prompt_templates.scenario: Test an API with OpenAPI spec
prompt_templates.prompt: Scan our API at https://api.example.com using the OpenAPI specification at ./openapi.yaml. Include authentication using the bearer token from environment variable API_TOKEN and generate JSON and HTML reports.

prompt_templates.title: Authenticated scan
prompt_templates.prompt: Run an authenticated scan against https://app.example.com using form-based authentication. The login page is at https://app.example.com/login, username is testuser, and password is in environment variable SCAN_PASSWORD.

prompt_templates.title: CI/CD integration
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a GitHub Actions workflow file for OWASP ZAP scanning that runs on pull requests, fails if high-risk findings are detected, and uploads SARIF results to the GitHub Security tab

output: Key issues found: Missing X-Frame-Options header, Cookie without Secure flag, Server information disclosure

output_examples.input: Scan API with OpenAPI spec and bearer token
output: SARIF report uploaded to GitHub Security tab

best_practices: Always obtain written authorization before scanning any system you do not own
Use baseline scans for every commit and full active scans only on staging environments
Never hardcode credentials; use environment variables or secrets management
Verify active scan findings manually before creating security tickets
anti_patterns: Running active scans against production systems without approval
Including real credentials in scan configurations or scripts
Ignoring false positive rates without investigation
Using scan results as the sole measure of application security

faq.question: What tools does this skill require?
faq.answer: Docker is required to run OWASP ZAP containers. Python 3 is optional for script support.

faq.question: What scan types are available?
faq.answer: Baseline (passive), Full (active), API, and Authenticated scans. Each targets different security testing needs.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with CI/CD?
faq.answer: Yes. GitHub Actions and GitLab CI templates are included. Supports SARIF format for GitHub Security tab.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: Scans run locally using Docker. No data is sent to external services. Target URLs and credentials stay in your environment.

faq.question: Why did the scan complete too quickly?
faq.answer: The spider may not have reached all pages. Increase depth with -z config options or use the AJAX spider for JavaScript apps.

faq.question: How does this compare to other scanners?
faq.answer: OWASP ZAP is a proxy-based DAST tool. Unlike SAST (source code analysis), it tests running applications from an attacker perspective.
